Description: Terracotta aryballos (mended from numerous fragments) in the form of a squatting man with hands clasped together, perhaps a komast or Silenos. Rimless mouth of vessel located on top of head; two drill holes on either side of head; black decoration representing hair on head, face, and pubic region; painted details on eyes and arms; painted dots all over body. Mould-made and hollow. Fine light grey fabric.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ8(?) (probably)
Curator's comments: Marked in pencil '8', (possibly Sanctuary of Aphrodite context 8). Parallels from Camirus, Rhodes in the British Museum (GR1860,0201.47, GR1860,0404.37, Higgins 1954, nos 1665, 1666) and from Perachora, near Corinth, dated to ca. 590BC (Payne 1940, pl.109 no.199). Previously thought to be Corinthian, now known to be of East Greek manufacture. For discussion of komast subject see Dasen (2010) and Mandel (2004). Dasen, V. 2010, ‘Squatting comasts and scarab-beetles’, in G.R. Tsteskhladze, A.J.N.W. Prag and A.M. Snodgrass (eds), Periplous: Papers on Classical Art and Archaeology Presented to Sir John Boardman, Oxford, 89–97. Mandel, U. 2004, ‘Ägyptische Schemata in ostgriechischer Aneignung: Figürliche salbgefässe und terrakotten des 6. Jahrhunderts V. Chr’, in H. Beck, P.C. Bol, G. Kaminski and C. Maderna (eds), Fremdheit – Eigenheit Ägypten, Griechenland und Rom Austausch und Verständnis, Städel Jahrbuch Neue Folge 19, Stuttgart, 47–71. Payne, H. 1940. 'Perachora I. The sanctuaries of Hera Akraia and Limenia: the architecture, bronzes and terracottas'. Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1667)
Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 57, pl. XV, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.032) (Phase 3)
